Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46184-001  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
August 2012 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Asian Development Outlook 2013
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS

Vice-President  B. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  J. E. Zveglich, Jr., Assistant Chief Economist, ERD 
Team members  E. Laviña, Senior Economics Officer, ERD 
  M. Lee, Senior Economist, ERD 
M. S. Torres, Senior Economics and Research Assistant, ERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Outlook  (ADO)  is  a  flagship  publication  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) that showcases ADB’s knowledge and expertise about the region. 
The report’s analysis provides insights into the economic issues faced by Asia and the Pacific, 
and appropriate policy responses. Its content informs ADB Management opinion and guides 
institutional views about the region’s macroeconomic prospects and important development 
issues. As such, there is a need to continuously come up with a high-quality analysis to remain 
a  relevant,  credible,  and  independent  source  of  information  about  the  region,  thereby 
maintaining its usefulness and relevance to policy dialogues and formulation in ADB developing 
member  countries  (DMCs).  The  production  of  the  ADO  has  been  regularly  supported  by 
technical assistance (TA) funding.1 The objectives, scope, and activities to be covered by the 
regional TA are in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The TA Strategic Forum 2008 recognized the important role that flagship publications 
such as the ADO play in monitoring the major economic issues and trends of ADB's DMCs. By 
regularly  providing  comprehensive  analysis  on  evolving  developments  in  DMCs,  the  ADO 
provides a basis for understanding the key drivers of, and constraints on, economic growth—a 
critical element for inclusive economic growth, which is one of the priority research areas under 
Strategy  2020.3 Also,  under  ADB’s  streamlined  business  processes,  the  ADO  has  been 
established as the main reference for the economic assessment and outlook section of country 
partnership strategies. 
 
3.  The ADO is one of the most frequently downloaded publications from ADB’s website.4 It 
is a source of much international and national news commentary that features analysis, views, 
and opinions from ADB. Thus, a concerted effort to produce a high-quality publication every 
year is vital to elevate the publication’s profile and to ensure its relevance and usefulness in 
research and policy dialogues and formulation in ADB DMCs. 
 
4.  In addition to the country-by-country and regional economic analyses, the ADO in its 
recent issues has featured timely topics on rebalancing growth, macroeconomic management 
beyond the global financial crisis, South–South economic links, and inequality in developing 
Asia. These are all important issues that have been brought to the fore in the wake of the recent 
global financial crisis. Discussion of these topics has important policy implications for developing 
Asia in sustaining long-term growth in the face of global uncertainties.  
 
5.  In keeping with its aim to present the vital and contemporary issues pertinent to the 
DMCs while tackling one of the development agendas of the region as envisioned in Strategy 
2020, the theme chapter of ADO 2013 will be ―Ensuring Energy Security in Asia and the Pacific.‖ 
                                                
1  ADO 2013 has been identified as a corporate priority TA in the 30 January 2012 memo on resource allocation for 
technical assistance operations in 2012. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 July 2012. 
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
4  From 2006 to 2012, the ADO and ADO Update have consistently ranked among the top ADB downloads from the 
month of launch until the following year. Their launches have regularly generated significant coverage from both 
global and regional top-tier media, such as the Financial Times, the Asian Wall Street Journal, and the International 
Herald Tribune.

2   
Developing Asia’s energy demand is projected to almost triple from 4,242 million tons of oil 
equivalent in 2007 to 11,480 million tons of oil equivalent by 2050, the highest rate among 
regions. Economies outside the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 
(OECD) would account for about 95% of the projected growth in global energy demand by 2050. 
The rapid growth of Asia’s energy demand over the next 3 decades will put extraordinary 
pressure on securing energy sources (Asia being the most responsible for and affected by 
excessive reliance on energy imports) and will generate a rapid increase in carbon dioxide 
emissions.5 Per  capita  energy  use  in  developing  Asia  is  about  a  third  that  of  developed 
countries and the projected rapid growth reflects the catch-up effect. Asia needs increasing 
energy supplies to sustain economic growth and development while energy resources are under 
pressure and the current level of energy-related carbon dioxide emissions threatens our climate. 
Energy  security  is  an  important  mission;  it  means  ensuring  long-term  supply  security  by 
promoting sufficient investment, ameliorating market volatility, and examining issues of energy 
balance accountability. The theme chapter will examine the energy issues underlying the long-
term view of the region articulated in Asia 2050: Realizing the Asian Century. In particular, it will 
discuss how much Asia’s long-term growth will contribute to energy demand in Asia and the 
world, how to ensure Asia’s energy security, the implications for environmentally sustainable 
growth, options for switching to a cleaner and more efficient energy future, and the policies 
needed to ensure energy security in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
6.  To motivate the discussion, the theme chapter will provide projections of developing 
Asia’s energy demand and supply under high- and low-growth scenarios. It will present country 
and subregional demand–supply analysis and will estimate the demand–supply gap in Asia’s 
power sector. Quantitative analysis to estimate energy demand reduction and carbon dioxide 
emission reduction through energy-efficiency-promoting policies for both high- and low-growth 
scenario  cases  will  also  be  conducted.  This  can  be  the  basis  of  an  assessment  of  the 
macroeconomic impacts on gross domestic product and employment generation, and financial 
impacts on energy bill savings of energy efficiency programs.  
 
7.  Finally, the theme chapter will draw conclusions about advantages and drawbacks of 
different  policies.  This  analysis  should  enable  countries  embarking  on  energy  demand 
management policies to benefit from the experience of other countries. The effect of the gradual 
rationalization of fossil-fuel subsidies on the energy mix, as well as its impacts on the macro 
economy and households, will also be discussed. Based on the analyses above, concrete and 
specific policy directions on how developing Asia as a region can ensure energy security and 
promote sustainable and low-carbon economic growth will be recommended. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be for the ADO to influence the environment within which policy 
formulation in selected DMCs occurs. The outcome will be citations of the ADO by the media, 
and by economic researchers within and outside ADB. Appendix 2 contains the outline of ADO 
2013 and ADO 2013 Update. 
 
                                                
5  ADB. 2011. Asia 2050: Realizing the Asian Century. Manila.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The main outputs of the TA will be the disseminated ADO 2013, ADO 2013 Update, and 
ADO  Supplement  reports.6 The  TA  will  support  the  following  key  activities:  (i)  preparing 
background analytical papers; (ii) further developing and refining analytical methods; (iii) drafting 
ADO content; (iv) economic editing and copyediting; (v) preparing and laying out materials for 
publication; and (vi) disseminating key results and policy messages. The TA will also support 
initiatives to build capacity for macroeconomic modeling, generating growth projections, and 
monitoring markets. These initiatives will be linked to a bigger plan within the Economics and 
Research Department (ERD), which aims to build a ―modeling culture‖ within ADB, and will 
include economists in the regional departments, especially those involved in the preparation of 
the  country  chapters,  and  possibly  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration.  Several 
activities for the preparation of ADO 2014 may be supported under the TA.  
 
10.  ERD must work continuously to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance of the 
report if it is to remain a credible, independent source of knowledge and information about Asia 
and  the  Pacific.  Background  research  papers  to  provide  a  solid  empirical  and  analytical 
foundation for ADO content will be produced under the TA. These papers will supplement the 
research work of the Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF) on the selected 
theme topics, analyzing issues and policy implications for the DMCs covered. These papers will 
be consolidated in an edited research volume to provide researchers with more extensive 
background information and analyses related to the theme topic. The research volume may be 
copublished with a reputable publishing house and will likely entail a buyback arrangement. 
 
11.  The  TA  will  support  the  development  and  refinement  of  analytical  methods  to 
supplement ADB’s short- and medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. This will 
strengthen the economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs, 
thereby creating better-informed and better-designed economic policies and enhancing ADB’s 
country assistance. 
 
12.  Workshops and conferences will be organized as part of ADO preparation to strengthen 
the content. The writers’ workshop will focus on macroeconomic analysis of current issues, 
growth accounting, economic projections and macroeconomic modeling, and effective writing 
skills. The workshop will target selected economists and national staff in regional departments 
and resident missions who are responsible for writing the country chapters. This will also impart 
skills that are of broader relevance to the economic and sector work, which underpins country 
strategies. The conferences will focus on the reports’ theme chapters. Distinguished economists 
from the region will be invited to discuss initial drafts of the background papers to improve the 
analytical rigor and policy relevance of the theme chapters. 
 
13.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the different parts 
of the ADO and the edited volume of background research papers, high-quality editing services 
will be provided by international consultants.  
 
14.  The publications will be widely disseminated in collaboration with the Department of 
External Relations (DER). The international media launch will be followed by presentations 
cohosted by ADB development partners within and outside Asia and the Pacific. The outreach 
                                                
6  The ADO Supplement is a short report jointly initiated with the Office of Regional Economic Integration to produce 
quarterly updates of macro forecasts between ADO and ADO Update releases.

4   
will include analytical discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions and 
think tanks. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA. 
Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, the chief economist will report to the vice-
president for knowledge management and sustainable development and the President at critical 
points in the publications’ preparation. The TA is expected to start in September 2012 and be 
completed by 30 June 2014. 
 
17.  The production of the ADO will be a joint effort (led by ERMF) of ERD economists, 
country  economists  of  the  regional  departments  and  resident  missions,  national  experts, 
international consultants, and economics editors. As in previous years, ERMF will collaborate 
with regional departments and resident missions on the preparation of the country chapters. 
ERD  will  also  coordinate  with  the  energy  divisions  of  the  regional  departments  and  the 
community of practice on energy in the preparation of the theme chapter. The theme topic for 
the ADO 2013 Update will be decided after consultations with the regional departments and 
Management. 
 
18.  The  TA  will  require  16  person-months  of  international  consultancy  resources  for 
economists who will prepare the background papers and analyses on the issue of the theme 
topic. In addition, the TA will require an estimated 24 person-months of international economic 
advisory  and  editing  consultants’  time  for  the  economic  and  technical  editing  of  ADO 
manuscripts before final publication of ADO 2013 and ADO 2013 Update. The TA will also 
require 7 person-months of national economic consultants’ time to assist in conducting research 
on  different macroeconomic  topics,  and another  13  person-months  will  be  needed for  the 
desktop publishing and graphic design requirements of the publication. Consultants will be hired 
as individuals.7 Resource persons will be engaged to conduct training on macroeconomics and 
economic forecasting and may also serve as discussants during the workshops. Consultants 
and resource persons will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 4.   
 
19.  The TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services, such as 
subscription to macroeconomic data providers (e.g., Bloomberg), as may be required to support 
relevant and up-to-date content. Equipment such as computers and software to support the 
macroeconomic modeling work will be purchased by ADB in accordance with its Procurement 
Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  in  coordination  with  the  Office  of 
Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  the  Office  of  Administrative  Services,  where 
                                                
7  The TA will involve independent studies and require rapid mobilization of consultants to ensure that there are no 
delays in the tight production schedule of the publications. In addition, the experience and qualifications of the 
individual consultants will be the primary considerations. Thus, the consultants will be hired on an individual basis.

5 
applicable. All computer equipment purchased under the TA will remain ADB’s property even 
after TA account closing, until disposed of.8 Disbursements under the TA will be in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
20.  Workshops will be conducted to review and discuss the initial country chapters and 
background papers prepared for the ADO. These are tentatively scheduled for December 2012, 
February 2013, May 2013, and July 2013 at the ADB headquarters. The TA may cover travel 
expenses of selected resident mission staff participating in the workshops as resource persons. 
 
21.  The TA will support the dissemination activities of ERD and DER. The major results and 
key policy messages emerging from the ADO 2013 and ADO 2013 Update will be disseminated 
to  the  media,  DMC  policymakers,  and  academic  communities.  The  media  launch  and 
subsequent  road  shows  will  be  undertaken  by  ERD  in  coordination  with  DER.  Separate 
launches will be undertaken by resident missions in selected DMCs in coordination with their 
regional departments and DER. Roundtable discussions and workshops in different academic 
and economic institutions will also be conducted to reach a wider audience. Both ADO 2013 and 
ADO  2013  Update  will  be featured  on the  ADB  website  and  copies,  either  in  print  or  on 
CD-ROMs, will be distributed worldwide. ADO Supplement reports will be produced in between 
the publication of the ADO and the ADO Update to provide updated assessment on the DMCs. 
The TA may also support the translation of the ADO into other languages, as may be required, 
to  support  dissemination  activities  in  selected  DMCs.  This  will  be  arranged  by  regional 
departments in coordination with the concerned resident missions and DER. 
 
22.  As team leader, the assistant chief economist (ACE), ERMF will monitor the work under 
the  TA  to  ensure  its  effective  implementation.  ERD  researchers  will  review  the  work  of 
consultants  engaged  to  verify  that  tasks  are  completed  in  accordance  with  the  terms  of 
reference, and that draft reports are delivered on time, with the ACE, ERMF managing the 
combined outputs of the consultants. Peer review of papers within ADB and, if possible, by 
other research and academic institutions will also be used as a tool to evaluate the quality and 
depth of analysis of the research papers. ACE, ERMF will set the production schedule, assure 
that adequate staff are assigned, and be responsible for meeting the deadlines for the timely 
delivery of publications. The success of the dissemination activities will be monitored through 
web download statistics and media monitoring reports provided by DER. 
 
23.  Evaluation of outputs and outcomes will be done to help measure the success of the TA. 
ERMF evaluation of the overall ADO process will be conducted to determine strengths and 
weaknesses as well as areas for improvement that will serve as inputs for the next ADO. 
Monitoring and back-to-office reports on the ADO and ADO Update launches will also be 
reviewed to gather feedback on the publications and learn lessons from them. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION   
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asian Development Outlook 2013, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  11 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economics Consultants (international, 16 person-months, 12 consultants) 
1.  The  consultants  should  have  excellent  working  experience  in  general 
macroeconomics—particularly specializing on energy issues for those that will be hired for the 
Asian Development Outlook (ADO) 2013—and a good knowledge of the developing member 
economies.  Under  the  direct  supervision  of  the  relevant  Macroeconomics  and  Finance 
Research Division (ERMF) staff, the consultants will 
(i)  prepare  analysis  essays  on  current  issues  and  country  reports  as  may  be 
assigned; 
(ii)  participate in ADO workshops as may be required; 
(iii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of the 
ADO;  
(iv)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist (ACE), ERMF; and 
(v)  deliver the following outputs: draft, revised, and final background papers. 
 
B.  Editorial Economic Advisors (international, 16 person-months, 8 consultants) 
2.  Under the direct supervision of ACE, ERMF and in coordination with other ADB staff 
involved in preparing the country chapters of ADO 2013 and ADO 2013 Update, the advisors 
will collaborate with authors in the development of country write-ups; and review the draft 
chapters for economic content and consistency with economic theory. The advisors will draft the 
subregional highlights of the publication and ensure that all the data in the publication are based 
on the most recent information available as of the specified cut-off date. The advisors will also 
act as resource persons in the ADO writers’ workshop to be held at the ADB headquarters. In 
particular, the advisors will 
(i)  work with the authors during the workshop to develop chapter outlines, key 
messages, and storylines of the country chapters; 
(ii)   work  with  the  authors—from  drafting,  revising,  and  finalizing  of  the  drafts; 
reviewing  the  drafts;  conducting  one-on-one  and  group  discussions  with  the 
authors; and providing advice on areas that can be strengthened and improved;  
(iii)   draft subregional highlights and summaries and related key messages; 
(iv)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the 
write-up; 
(v)  work with the manuscript editor in finalizing the text of the country chapters in 
consultation with the authors; 
(vi)  review press releases and related materials for the ADO;  
(vii)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by ACE, 
ERMF; and 
(viii)  deliver the following outputs: edited country chapters and highlights.  
 
C.  Economics Editor (international, 2 person-months, 2 consultants) 
 
3.  Under the direct supervision of ACE, ERMF and in consultation with other ADB staff in 
the Economics and Research Department (ERD) involved in preparing and reviewing the theme 
chapter, the economics editor will edit the theme chapter for economic content. In particular, the 
economics editor will 
(i)  edit the theme chapter for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical 
evidence, and include some redrafting of the text along the following lines:

14  Appendix 4 
 
 
 
G.  Economics Consultants (national, 7 person-months, 2 consultants) 
 
8.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general economics. Under 
the  direct  supervision  of  relevant  ERMF  staff,  the  consultants  will  assist  in  the  economic 
research work of ERD and undertake general economic research. The assignment will be at the 
ADB headquarters, Manila. In particular, the consultants will 
(i)  conduct research  on  issues  related  to macroeconomic  development, growth, 
trade and investment, human capital development, and long-term employment 
generation in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  support country economic analyses; 
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of the ADO and its update; 
(iv)  update the ADO data sheet;  
(v)  undertake ad hoc research and other assignments as may be assigned by ACE, 
ERMF; and 
(vi)  deliver the following outputs: updated database, charts, and tables; draft and final 
reports (as may be required).
